In my view the top doctors are ones who answer all your questions, take the time to make sure you understand, have a little humanity and view you as a person as well as a patient, and don't give you the creeps. They are also competent in their fields and are thoughtful in their referrals. I had an oral surgeon who gave me the creeps, and happily got my work done by his colleague who was a nice guy.

In the last four years I have also acquired an ENT/neck surgeon, a radiation oncologist, a gastroenterologist, a new primary care doctor, and a new optometrist. And my daughter has the same new primary care and a new neurologist. I like them all--they're tops in my book--good at what they do and human as well.
Spot on.  Let's not forget her very friendly relations with Rupert Murdoch over the years.  Another word for 'centrist" is "corporatist."

Seriously? You think that Hillary is genuinely so bad that we might as well elect Ted Cruz, Chris Christie, Rick Santorum, Bobby Jindal, Marco Rubio, Paul Ryan, Rand Paul, Scott Walker or even Jeb Bush?

Seriously?

I don't like her reflexive hawkishness or corporate-ness either, but since all of her likely opponents would essentially work for or agree to eliminating voting rights, outlawing abortion (and/or contraception), reducing the highest individual tax bracket to zero (along with corporate taxes), eliminating the feeble efforts being made by the US to combat climate change, drilling and/or fracking every square inch of public land, eliminating the ACA, further loosening gun laws, etc., I will vote for her or any Democrat over the willfully ignorant, willfully blind, scorched-earthed Republican machine.

The world would be a much better place if an Elizabeth Warren could be elected President, but it is not the world in which we live. Hillary Clinton is light years ahead of any potential GOP nominee. At the very least she lives in the current century.
Pretty well sums it up.

"she has ascended to some level of saturation exposure that’s above and beyond omnipresent. At this point she’s practically ambient."

She is setting all time records for name recognition. But, big but, an awful lot of us who know her know we hate her.

She is scooping up as Liberal Hawks the Neocons who lost power under the Republicans. She is not just to the right of Obama, she is out there with McCain. She is the evil secret that has been hiding among the Dems -- they say one thing but do what she is.

I'd rather vote for anybody but Hillary, even a Republican, so at least they take the blame for doing what Republicans do.

Even Obama has failed to stand up to them, but Hillary is co-opting them. It is Clinton's triangulation run wild.

So yeah, everybody knows who she is. And what she is.

THANK YOU, Tim, for bringing up the true financial cost of the two Wars. In early 2013, Linda Bilmes of Harvard (co-author with J. Stiglitz 2008's The $3 Trillion War) put the cost at $4-$6 trillion...and this may be an understatement in not reflecting state government costs or the gross understaffing of the VA.

I so wish this paper had the courage to assess the greater appropriateness of her numbers compared to the CBO's more limited cost definitions. The $4-$6 Trillion numbers need to be mainstreamed. I think President Obama's approval rating would be at 85% if Americans really understood how much less their Medicare would have to be cut without this war, and how we could have infrastructure like faster trains and fewer scary instances of toxic water like Toledo.
Consider Senator Bernie Sanders.

What I am exhausted by is the inexhaustible vigor of those who continue to want America to 'step up to the plate', to engage in the Middle East militarily, as if the Bush Cheney twin debacles of Afghanistan and Iraq never happened. It has been projected that when all is said and done, these two conflicts will have accrued somewhere between $4-5 trillion to the federal deficit, no small amount or percentage of a $17 trillion deficit which continues to rise, though a little more slowly. The needless loss of tens of thousands of lives.

Some will argue that our recent efforts against ISIS in Iraq have accomplished something, certainly the humanitarian effort by our nation and others is laudatory. But in an article in the Guardian today, it was noted that a top U.S. general thinks that what we have done will have little long term effect on ISIS, and that these adaptable, organized terrorists are doing exactly what Dick Cheney himself had predicted in 1992, weaving themselves in amongst the civilian populations. Does this then mean escalation is all but inevitable or despite the slings and arrows of hawks, that our president will not ... escalate.

I would welcome the opportunity to vote for the non Hillary, the non Clinton and certainly the non McCain, what statesmen do we have that genuinely mean to restrain foreign involvements in the possible candidates who may present themselves for 2016? Does such a person, honest and forthcoming, really exist?

I echo the thoughts of those kind others who lament the effect that mental illness has upon us.  However, I hope that you will understand that science, medicine, and other similar disciplines have not yet found an overall effective way to deal with profound depression.  Perhaps someday, but the lack of such approach is likely behind today's tragedy.  Mr. Williams tried, but could not defeat, the monster.  Those of us who have also tried and at least partially succeeded applaud his efforts and wish his spirit well.

then think of his pain.
Do you seriously think he did not live his family?
But his own pain was unendurable.
Feel sorrow for him, and try a little understanding.

A broken foot you see. And you make allowances for the one in a cast who walks slowly.

a broken spirit ... a soul in pain ... society condemns. How sad and selfish.

Yes, dollars to local and national organizations fighting mental illness, plus grassroots demand for better treatment options in all health insurance policies.  If we can provide much better support to children suffering early signs of disturbance, we will save lives and -- if we need $ justification -- money in social services and criminal justice.

Imagine? 99% of it would go to the system feeding off the suffering. As it does now. Everyone must ask this question in every suicide: were there any psychotropic, psychiatric drugs involved? Who was prescribing? If you want to help those suffering, challenge the status quo to prescribe, prescribe, prescribe drugs that can escalate mood disorders to suicidal (homicidal) despair and mania faster than you can say "What happened?" Lurking in the shadows of these tragedies are villains as dangerous and impervious as any cocaine drug baron. Psychiatrists and others who dole out poison pills guessing and wishing it might help, there's very little knowing, still in 2014. And no accountability. Poor Robin. God Bless Him.

A genius, yet also so imperfectly human. May his loved ones find comfort in knowing that his pain is gone. Especially his children. My father lost a similar battle around the same age, and in grieving I was relieved that my dad's suffering was over. Imagine if we all gave $10 to mental health research....
Like Sinatra and  Fred Astaire (and a few others that could be named) ... he is irreplacable.  I think this day and week: millions will be mourning and missing him.

Hearing the news tonight I felt the same sadness I felt when John Belushi died. A person who brought so much happiness to so many. Wish they could have felt it from our side, wish things were easier, better for both of them.

Thanks Robin. You gave us all sorts of laughter, tears, and kept it real. Thanks for the grace in which you attacked racism, homophobia and all social injustice. You were a kind and generous neighbor-kids congregated from everywhere to collect those fat candy bars at Halloween. Maybe that's why you moved from San Francisco to Tiburon. You asked for little in return. I saw you a few months ago walking down the street with the Mrs-you didn't look well. I nodded ever so slightly and kept going. Oh would it be that any one of us could have helped a scintilla of what you have given us.

Ave atque valle, for you are one for the ages.

Understanding Robin Williams death is not in my power, nor anyone else's I believe. It's enough to know our hearts are heavy and we shall miss this icon of laughter and happiness. We should laugh and smile when thinking of all he generously gave to us, it's the least we can do for someone who brought the world such joy.

Such sad news. He always let his humanity shine through his work, standup or movie, he was all in.
He was so open about his difficulties it feels like we've lost a family member.
Condolences to his family. Having worked in mental health most of my life please believe me: there's nothing you could have done. The disease creates its own reasoning. 'They'll be better off w/o me' is one example of BP's insidious worming into the mind at its lowest points. He fought the disease heroically and the world loved his genius that beamed through in spite of his struggles.
Maybe this tragic loss will bring light to the lack of relief for BP and depression which affects a large % of our population, and spur more research into effective treatment options.
He was the clown with the broken heart.  Yet he never tried to drag others down with him during his life here.  May he have a peaceful eternity!

Robin Williams paid great tribute to the human characters he conjured so well. Now may we, with the same artful insight and taste, pay him sad and heartfelt homage.

Robin, may the peace of God restore and uplift your spirit as you have done so often for others. As John Donne said (in "Death be not proud"): "Die not, poor death, nor yet canst thou kill me. From rest and sleep, which but thy pictures be, /Much pleasure; then from thee much more must flow,/And soonest our best men with thee do go."

Yet, in the end, "One short sleep past, we wake eternally,/And death shall be no more, death thou shalt die." May Robin's rich legacy and wonderful film legacy live on long, well and deeply for all seasons!

Sounds like these schoolchildren already have to deal with the issue raised a few weeks ago about parents who obsessively check their messages. When do you parents get to say 'all devices off!'
Teachers should post assignments before homework time might begin. You should talk to them about this.

The parents should take up this issue strongly with the teachers concerned as well as the Principal for systematically organising the entire process or else they should abandon it and resort to the good old method.

Ask the administrators at your child's school for consistency in website design and structure, when homework assignments are assigned and due, and how they are accepted electronically.  Having to haunt one's computer while waiting on the teachers after hours seems really counter-productive.

Last week's thread about student organization got me thinking about ways my son could better keep track of assignments. But the more I think about it, the more difficult it seems. My son's school requires teachers to post grades and assignments online, which seems like it would eliminate all sorts of problems for the disorganized student. And it does eliminate some--but at the cost of creating many, many others. The worst problem so far has been that some teachers really take to heart the flexibility made available by the online environment, and homework is sometimes posted hours after the school day has ended. But the student doesn't know when an assignment will appear, so throughout the afternoon and evening he has to return repeatedly to the teacher's blog (or reporting system, or email blast, or moodle, or whatever other seemingly random and unique medium is selected by that individual teacher). Another significant problem my son experienced was that each teacher required different methods for submitting homework online, and there were frequent glitches. In one teacher's system, my son couldn't always tell if an assignment had been "accepted," which led to repeated attempts, emails to the teacher ("I'm not sure my assignment logged in so just in case I am sending you a screenshot..."), printing out a copy as a backup, anxiety about whether the teacher would give credit....

What a frustration. Bring back the old days, when a lost paper was the only obstacle.

Animals should not suffer. Domesticated animals are a rarity -- a point Jared Diamond writes about in "Guns, Germs and Steel."  "The Selfish Gene," and other such books make a good case that life, animate or plant, is really a means of perpetuating genes and not individuals. Domesticated animals -- their genes anyway -- made a deal with humans about 8,000 years ago:  Increase our numbers, improve our reproductive success, and we'll be domesticated.  A macro biologist would call it symbiosis or mutualism on a species scale. The bible would say:  humans have dominion over all creation. And dogs -- give companionship, not food. But in the deal we owe it to all our domesticated partners -- no suffering.
Sometimes, Deb, I have the feeling I am not here.

So terribly sad. We have all lost a great entertainer, performer, and comedic talent. Someone who held a mirror up to life and allowed us to laugh...what a gift to us! I recall the times I saw him interviewed, his intense energy and keen wit, able to impersonate and improvise on a dime--who does that? And when he spoke of addiction, I'd think, "of course." With that frenetic energy and intellect, life at regular speed could hardly be enough. Given my own experience with depression and a bipolar sibling, and far too much familial mental illness and addiction, I reflect how we've lost *yet another* talented, brilliant, and wonderful person to the darkness that creeps in. May his experience remind us of the many others who battle on a daily basis, and may we find more ways to help and support them so they, too, don't die far too soon. His pain is over. May he rest in peace, and my thoughts with his family.
...a comic genius and prolific actor, we will never understand the suffering behind his gentle eyes. RIP Robin
He is part of me and I would assume part of many other people as well.
